data.title: Add method override indicators
data.body:
Currently vscode does not show override indicators that the current class is overriding/implementing methods from super class/interface.

This indicator would help the user understand that the given method is being overridden rather than a local method.

Most editors such as intellij & eclipse have these indicators

It would make the code look much cleaner if the editor allows the ability to fold/expand the imports in languages such as typescript & java

data.title: JavaScript formatter: Place else on separate line
Support for regex test along the lines of IntelliJ

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Intellij allows us to check regex against arbitrary string to validate any regex within code.

This feature also escapes the regex characters appropriately according to the language of the file the user is editing.

This would a "nice to have" feature in vscode.

Reference:
https://blog.jetbrains.com/idea/2011/11/regexp/

data.title: Intellisense not working with Python 3.6
data.body:
Intellisense not working with Python 3.6. Python extension hasn't the 3.6 grammer file.

Solution:
copy grammar3.5.txt to grammar3.6.txt in ~\.vscode-insiders\extensions\donjayamanne.python-0.5.5\pythonFiles\preview\jedi\parser and my autocompletion started to work again.

data.title: ES2015 import from './css' incorrectly links to .../css/index.d.ts instead of my own css.js
data.body:
I have a file `css.js` and I `import css from './css.js'` in another module in the same directory.

`'./css.js'` seems to be interpreted by the editor as a link to `/Users/me/Library/Application Support/Microsoft/TypeScript/node_modules/@types/css/index.d.ts`, rather than my `css.js` module.

Problems:

1. cmd+click on `'./css.js'` incorrectly links to `/Users/me/Library/Application Support/Microsoft/TypeScript/node_modules/@types/css/index.d.ts`.
2. Intellisense does not work on the `css` variable - nothing from my `css.js` module is suggested

Observations: 
* `import css from 'css'` also links to `index.d.ts`
* `import css from './css.js'` (with js extension) correctly links to my `css.js` file
* `import css from '../mydir/css'` correctly links to my `css.js` file
* changing the import variable name from `css` to `somethingElse` has no effect - same problems occur.


This was not an issue until very recently - only noticed it in the last week or so, and the behaviour changed for existing code where previously the linking was working fine. I suspect it was introduced with v1.8.1.

---
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create a file `css.js` and a file `other.js` in the same directory
2. `export default { a: 1, b: 2 }` from `css.js`
3. `import css as './css'` in `other.js`
4. cmd+click `'./css'` in the editor, see the incorrect navigation to `../css/index.d.js`
5. notice that intellisense on `css.` in `other.js`does not suggest `css.a` or `css.b`
---

data.title: Can't start node debugger when "node" is a function in the shell

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.2

I recognize that I'm in "special snowflake" territory with my setup here, and definitely don't expect first-class support for what I'm doing, but it feels like the kind of thing VS Code could handle more gracefully than it currently does. Basically this is a stranger occurrence of #10571. 

The [zsh port of nvm](https://github.com/lukechilds/zsh-nvm) has a side effect of slowing down shell startups; to mitigate this, it has a lazy loading functionality that has node, npm, and any other installed binaries defined as functions at shell startup. On first invocation, they load up Node properly and everything proceeds hunky dory. (Thus you only incur the delay when you're actually using Node.) 

This seems to be interfering with VS Code's ability to figure out the environment -- I'm guessing that when it loads a fresh shell at startup and pulls its environment, the function definitions don't play a role (nor should they). 

If I start code from a command line where the lazy loading has already been done, the debugger works fine. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install zsh and the [zsh port of nvm](https://github.com/lukechilds/zsh-nvm). Make them your default shell.
2. In your .zshrc, `export NVM_LAZY_LOAD=true` before `source`-ing `zsh-nvm/zsh-nvm.plugin.zsh`.
3. Try to debug a Node.js project in VS Code. 
4. Note "Cannot find runtime 'node' on PATH" error.
5. Close down VS Code, open a terminal, and run `node -v`. Then invoke `code` on a directory containing a Node.js project. 
6. Note that you can successfully debug this project.
6. Close down VS Code, remove the NVM_LAZY_LOAD export from .zshrc, and restart VS Code.
7. Note that the debugger now can find Node.

data.title: VSCode doesn't start and stays quiet when Prefs folder doesn't exist

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Delete or temporarily rename the folder `%APPDATA%\Code\User`
2. Try to start VSCode

Notice how VSCode doesn't start at all. Luckily you still get a warning when running Code with `--verbose`

    Startup error: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat 'C:\Users\niklas\AppData\Roaming\Code\User'

This warning should be displayed in a dialog box or something.

data.title: Extensions cannot activate with allowJs compiler option
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16, Linux x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new extension using `yo generator-code`
2. Build, debug and activate the new extension to check it works.
3. Add a pure JavaScript (.js) file to the project.
4. As per the documentation, add the following to `compilerOptions` in *tsconfig.json*:

`"allowJs": true`

5. Relaunch the debugging session. The extension now fails to activate.
6. Remove the `allowJs` option from compilerOptions and restart debugging. The extension is able to activate again.

The errors reported in the debugger console when the extension fails to load always look like this:

> Activating extension myextension.foo failed: {1}.
> Activating extension myextension.foo failed:  undefined
> Here is the error stack:  undefined
> 

I've tried manually adding the `--allowJs` option into *.vscode/tasks.json* - with the same result.

data.title: [folding] Support single shortcut for toggling fold/unfold

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently we have the possibility to fold and unfold using different shortcuts. 

I would like to have "editor.toggleFold" option as well so I can have a single shortcut for that (e.g. Ctrl+M, Ctrl+M as in VS.NET)

E.g.:
{
        "key": "ctrl+1",
        "command": "editor.toggleFold",
        "when": "editorTextFocus"
    }

That way, I only have to remember a single shortcut for this and matches various other functionality in vscode. (e.g. toggle line comments/block comments, etc).

A toggle case (upper and lower) would also be nice as mentioned here. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16895

data.title: Support macOS alias on folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:42:49.304Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.3.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.11|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.7|
|vscode-npm|fknop|3.3.0|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.2|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a folder alias in Finder
2. Try to access files inside that folder alias from Visual Studio Code - Explorer

Code tries to open the alias as a file and then shows a messages about binary, size or incompatible codification.
